an5.120:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ niraye.
an5.120:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a nun with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.120:1.3.eng: Without examining or scrutinizing, she praises those deserving of criticism,

an5.120:1.4.eng: and criticizes those deserving of praise.

an5.120:1.7.eng: and wastes gifts given in faith.

an5.120:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ niraye.
an5.120:1.8.eng: A nun with these five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.120:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge.
an5.120:2.1.eng: A nun with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.120:2.3.eng: After examining and scrutinizing, she criticizes those deserving of criticism,

an5.120:2.4.eng: and praises those deserving of praise.

an5.120:2.7.eng: and doesn’t waste gifts given in faith.

an5.120:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgatā bhikkhunī yathābhataṃ nikkhittā evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.120:2.8.eng: A nun with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.121:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an5.121:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an5.121:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena gilānasālā tenupasaṅkami.
an5.121:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where

an5.121:1.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ dubbalaṃ gilānakaṃ;
an5.121:1.3.eng: he saw a certain mendicant who was weak and sick.

an5.121:1.4.eng: He sat down on the seat spread out,

an5.121:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ dubbalaṃ gilānakaṃ pañca dhammā na vijahanti, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
an5.121:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, if a weak and sick mendicant does not neglect five things, it can be expected that

an5.121:2.2.pli: ‘nacirasseva āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissatī’ti.
an5.121:2.2.eng: they will soon realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an5.121:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī, maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṃ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.
an5.121:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.

an5.121:3.3.pli: Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṃ dubbalaṃ gilānakaṃ ime pañca dhammā na vijahanti, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
an5.121:3.3.eng: If a weak and sick mendicant does not neglect these five things, it can be expected that

an5.121:3.4.eng: they will soon realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

an5.122:1.1.pli: “Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā pañca dhamme bhāveti pañca dhamme bahulīkaroti, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
an5.122:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, any monk or nun who develops and cultivates five qualities can expect one of two results:

an5.122:1.2.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.
an5.122:1.2.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

an5.122:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ajjhattaññeva sati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti dhammānaṃ udayatthagāminiyā paññāya, asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī.
an5.122:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has well established mindfulness inside themselves in order to understand the arising and passing away of phenomena, meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observes the impermanence of all conditions.

an5.122:2.3.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā ime pañca dhamme bhāveti ime pañca dhamme bahulīkaroti, tassa dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
an5.122:2.3.eng: Any monk or nun who develops and cultivates these five qualities can expect one of two results:

an5.122:2.4.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā”ti.
an5.122:2.4.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

an5.123:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato gilāno dūpaṭṭhāko hoti.
an5.123:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a patient with five qualities is hard to care for.

an5.123:1.3.pli: Asappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṃ na jānāti, bhesajjaṃ nappaṭisevitā hoti, atthakāmassa gilānupaṭṭhākassa na yathābhūtaṃ ābādhaṃ āvikattā hoti abhikkamantaṃ vā abhikkamatīti paṭikkamantaṃ vā paṭikkamatīti ṭhitaṃ vā ṭhitoti, uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ anadhivāsakajātiko hoti.
an5.123:1.3.eng: They do what is unsuitable. They don’t know moderation in what is suitable. They don’t take their medicine. Though their carer wants what’s best for them, they don’t accurately report their symptoms by saying when they’re getting worse, getting better, or staying the same. And they cannot endure physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

an5.123:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato gilāno dūpaṭṭhāko hoti.
an5.123:1.4.eng: A patient with these five qualities is hard to care for.

an5.123:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato gilāno sūpaṭṭhāko hoti.
an5.123:2.1.eng: A patient with five qualities is easy to care for.

an5.123:2.3.pli: Sappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṃ jānāti, bhesajjaṃ paṭisevitā hoti, atthakāmassa gilānupaṭṭhākassa yathābhūtaṃ ābādhaṃ āvikattā hoti abhikkamantaṃ vā abhikkamatīti paṭikkamantaṃ vā paṭikkamatīti ṭhitaṃ vā ṭhitoti, uppannānaṃ sārīrikānaṃ vedanānaṃ dukkhānaṃ tibbānaṃ kharānaṃ kaṭukānaṃ asātānaṃ amanāpānaṃ pāṇaharānaṃ adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
an5.123:2.3.eng: They do what is suitable. They know moderation in what is suitable. They take their medicine. Because their carer wants what’s best for them, they accurately report their symptoms by saying when they’re getting worse, getting better, or staying the same. And they can endure physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.

an5.123:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato gilāno sūpaṭṭhāko hotī”ti.
an5.123:2.4.eng: A patient with these five qualities is easy to care for.”

an5.124:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato gilānupaṭṭhāko nālaṃ gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ.
an5.124:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a carer with five qualities is not competent to care for a patient.

an5.124:1.4.pli: sappāyāsappāyaṃ na jānāti, asappāyaṃ upanāmeti, sappāyaṃ apanāmeti;
an5.124:1.4.eng: They don’t know what is suitable and unsuitable, so they supply what is unsuitable and remove what is suitable.

an5.124:1.5.eng: They care for the sick for the sake of material benefits, not out of love.

an5.124:1.6.pli: jegucchī hoti uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā vantaṃ vā kheḷaṃ vā nīharituṃ;
an5.124:1.6.eng: They’re disgusted to remove feces, urine, vomit, or spit.

an5.124:1.7.pli: nappaṭibalo hoti gilānaṃ kālena kālaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetuṃ samādapetuṃ samuttejetuṃ sampahaṃsetuṃ.
an5.124:1.7.eng: They’re unable to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the patient with a Dhamma talk from time to time.

an5.124:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato gilānupaṭṭhāko nālaṃ gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ.
an5.124:1.8.eng: A carer with these five qualities is not competent to care for a patient.

an5.124:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato gilānupaṭṭhāko alaṃ gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ.
an5.124:2.1.eng: A carer with five qualities is competent to care for a patient.

an5.124:2.4.pli: sappāyāsappāyaṃ jānāti, asappāyaṃ apanāmeti, sappāyaṃ upanāmeti;
an5.124:2.4.eng: They know what is suitable and unsuitable, so they remove what is unsuitable and supply what is suitable.

an5.124:2.5.eng: They care for the sick out of love, not for the sake of material benefits.

an5.124:2.6.pli: ajegucchī hoti uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā vantaṃ vā kheḷaṃ vā nīharituṃ;
an5.124:2.6.eng: They’re not disgusted to remove feces, urine, vomit, or spit.

an5.124:2.7.pli: paṭibalo hoti gilānaṃ kālena kālaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetuṃ samādapetuṃ samuttejetuṃ sampahaṃsetuṃ.
an5.124:2.7.eng: They’re able to educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire the patient with a Dhamma talk from time to time.

an5.124:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato gilānupaṭṭhāko alaṃ gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātun”ti.
an5.124:2.8.eng: A carer with these five qualities is competent to care for a patient.”

an5.125:1.3.pli: Asappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṃ na jānāti, apariṇatabhojī ca hoti, akālacārī ca hoti, abrahmacārī ca.
an5.125:1.3.eng: Doing what is unsuitable, not knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food unfit for consumption, activity at unsuitable times, and unchastity.

an5.125:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā anāyussā.
an5.125:1.4.eng: These are the five things that impede longevity.

an5.125:2.3.pli: Sappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṃ jānāti, pariṇatabhojī ca hoti, kālacārī ca hoti, brahmacārī ca.
an5.125:2.3.eng: Doing what is suitable, knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food fit for consumption, activity at suitable times, and chastity.

an5.125:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā āyussā”ti.
an5.125:2.4.eng: These are the five things that promote longevity.”

an5.126:1.3.pli: Asappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṃ na jānāti, apariṇatabhojī ca hoti, dussīlo ca, pāpamitto ca.
an5.126:1.3.eng: Doing what is unsuitable, not knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food unfit for consumption, unethical behavior, and bad friends.

an5.126:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā anāyussā.
an5.126:1.4.eng: These are the five things that impede longevity.

an5.126:2.3.pli: Sappāyakārī hoti, sappāye mattaṃ jānāti, pariṇatabhojī ca hoti, sīlavā ca, kalyāṇamitto ca.
an5.126:2.3.eng: Doing what is suitable, knowing moderation in what is suitable, eating food fit for consumption, ethical conduct, and good friends.

an5.126:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dhammā āyussā”ti.
an5.126:2.4.eng: These are the five things that promote longevity.”

an5.127:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nālaṃ saṅghamhā vapakāsituṃ.
an5.127:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is not fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.

an5.127:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, kāmasaṅkappabahulo ca viharati.
an5.127:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is not content with any kind of robe, almsfood, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they have a lot of sensual thoughts.

an5.127:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nālaṃ saṅghamhā vapakāsituṃ.
an5.127:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is not fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.

an5.127:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ saṅghamhā vapakāsituṃ.
an5.127:2.1.eng: A mendicant with five qualities is fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.

an5.127:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, nekkhammasaṅkappabahulo ca viharati.
an5.127:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is content with any kind of robe, almsfood, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they think a lot about renunciation.

an5.127:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ saṅghamhā vapakāsitun”ti.
an5.127:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is fit to live apart from a Saṅgha community.”

an5.128:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of suffering for an ascetic.

an5.128:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṃ carati.
an5.128:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is not content with any kind of robe, almsfood, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.

an5.128:1.4.eng: These are five kinds of suffering for an ascetic.

an5.128:2.1.eng: There are these five kinds of happiness for an ascetic.

an5.128:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, santuṭṭho hoti itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, abhirato ca brahmacariyaṃ carati.
an5.128:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is content with any kind of robe, almsfood, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they lead the spiritual life satisfied.

an5.128:2.4.eng: These are five kinds of happiness for an ascetic.”

an5.129:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these five fatal wounds lead to a place of loss, to hell.

an5.129:1.3.pli: Mātā jīvitā voropitā hoti, pitā jīvitā voropito hoti, arahaṃ jīvitā voropito hoti, tathāgatassa duṭṭhena cittena lohitaṃ uppāditaṃ hoti, saṅgho bhinno hoti.
an5.129:1.3.eng: Murdering your mother or father or a perfected one; maliciously shedding the blood of a Realized One; and causing a schism in the Saṅgha.

an5.129:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca āpāyikā nerayikā parikuppā atekicchā”ti.
an5.129:1.4.eng: These five fatal wounds lead to a place of loss, to hell.”

an5.13:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an5.130:1.3.eng: Loss of relatives, wealth, health, ethics, and view.

an5.130:1.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sattā ñātibyasanahetu vā bhogabyasanahetu vā rogabyasanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
an5.130:1.4.eng: It is not because of loss of relatives, wealth, or health that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.130:1.5.pli: Sīlabyasanahetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhibyasanahetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti.
an5.130:1.5.eng: It is because of loss of ethics or view that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.130:2.3.eng: Endowment with relatives, wealth, health, ethics, and view.

an5.130:2.4.pli: Na, bhikkhave, sattā ñātisampadāhetu vā bhogasampadāhetu vā ārogyasampadāhetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
an5.130:2.4.eng: It is not because of endowment with relatives, wealth, or health that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.130:2.5.pli: Sīlasampadāhetu vā, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhisampadāhetu vā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
an5.130:2.5.eng: It is because of endowment with ethics or view that sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.131:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rājā cakkavattī dhammeneva cakkaṃ vatteti;
an5.131:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, possessing five factors a wheel-turning monarch wields power only in a principled manner.

an5.131:1.2.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena pāṇinā.
an5.131:1.2.eng: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.

an5.131:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī atthaññū ca hoti, dhammaññū ca, mattaññū ca, kālaññū ca, parisaññū ca.
an5.131:2.2.eng: A wheel-turning monarch knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.

an5.131:2.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rājā cakkavattī dhammeneva cakkaṃ pavatteti;
an5.131:2.3.eng: A wheel-turning monarch who possesses these five factors wields power only in a principled manner.

an5.131:2.4.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena pāṇinā.
an5.131:2.4.eng: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.

an5.131:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammeneva anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavatteti;
an5.131:3.1.eng: In the same way, possessing five qualities a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.

an5.131:3.2.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.131:3.2.eng: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.131:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho atthaññū, dhammaññū, mattaññū, kālaññū, parisaññū.
an5.131:4.2.eng: A Realized One knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.

an5.131:4.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammeneva anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavatteti;
an5.131:4.3.eng: Possessing these five qualities a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.

an5.131:4.4.pli: taṃ hoti dhammacakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
an5.131:4.4.eng: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.”

an5.132:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño cakkavattissa jeṭṭho putto pitarā pavattitaṃ cakkaṃ dhammeneva anuppavatteti;
an5.132:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, possessing five factors a wheel-turning monarch’s eldest son continues to wield the power set in motion by his father only in a principled manner.

an5.132:1.2.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena pāṇinā.
an5.132:1.2.eng: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.

an5.132:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño cakkavattissa jeṭṭho putto atthaññū ca hoti, dhammaññū ca, mattaññū ca, kālaññū ca, parisaññū ca.
an5.132:2.2.eng: A wheel-turning monarch’s oldest son knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.

an5.132:2.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño cakkavattissa jeṭṭho putto pitarā pavattitaṃ cakkaṃ dhammeneva anuppavatteti;
an5.132:2.3.eng: A wheel-turning monarch’s oldest son who possesses these five factors continues to wield the power set in motion by his father only in a principled manner.

an5.132:2.4.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena pāṇinā.
an5.132:2.4.eng: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.

an5.132:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto tathāgatena anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ sammadeva anuppavatteti;
an5.132:3.1.eng: In the same way, possessing five qualities Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by the Realized One.

an5.132:3.2.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmiṃ.
an5.132:3.2.eng: And that wheel cannot be turned back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.

an5.132:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sāriputto atthaññū, dhammaññū, mattaññū, kālaññū, parisaññū.
an5.132:4.2.eng: Sāriputta knows what is right, knows principle, knows moderation, knows the right time, and knows the assembly.

an5.132:4.3.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto tathāgatena anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ sammadeva anuppavatteti;
an5.132:4.3.eng: Possessing these five qualities Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by the Realized One.

an5.132:4.4.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
an5.132:4.4.eng: And that wheel cannot be turned back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.”

an5.133:1.1.pli: “Yopi so, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā, sopi na arājakaṃ cakkaṃ vattetī”ti.
an5.133:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, even a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, does not wield power without having their own king.”

an5.133:1.2.pli: Evaṃ vutte aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.133:1.2.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,

an5.133:1.3.pli: “ko pana, bhante, rañño cakkavattissa dhammikassa dhammarañño rājā”ti?
an5.133:1.3.eng: “But who is the king of the wheel-turning monarch, the just and principled king?”

an5.133:1.4.eng: “It is principle, monk,” said the Buddha.

an5.133:2.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaññeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati antojanasmiṃ.
an5.133:2.1.eng: “Monk, a wheel-turning monarch provides just protection and security for his court, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.

an5.133:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaññeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati khattiyesu anuyantesu …pe… balakāyasmiṃ brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
an5.133:3.1.eng: He provides just protection and security for his aristocrats, vassals, troops, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.

an5.133:3.2.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhu, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaññeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā antojanasmiṃ dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā khattiyesu anuyantesu balakāyasmiṃ brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu dhammeneva cakkaṃ pavatteti;
an5.133:3.2.eng: When he has done this, he wields power only in a principled manner.

an5.133:3.3.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena pāṇinā.
an5.133:3.3.eng: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.

an5.133:4.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhu, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaññeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati bhikkhūsu:
an5.133:4.1.eng: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security for the monks, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.

an5.133:4.2.pli: ‘evarūpaṃ kāyakammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ kāyakammaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
an5.133:4.2.eng: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated. This kind of bodily action should not be cultivated.

an5.133:4.3.pli: evarūpaṃ vacīkammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ vacīkammaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
an5.133:4.3.eng: This kind of verbal action should be cultivated. This kind of verbal action should not be cultivated.

an5.133:4.4.pli: evarūpaṃ manokammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ manokammaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
an5.133:4.4.eng: This kind of mental action should be cultivated. This kind of mental action should not be cultivated.

an5.133:4.5.pli: evarūpo ājīvo sevitabbo, evarūpo ājīvo na sevitabbo;
an5.133:4.5.eng: This kind of livelihood should be cultivated. This kind of livelihood should not be cultivated.

an5.133:4.6.pli: evarūpo gāmanigamo sevitabbo, evarūpo gāmanigamo na sevitabbo’ti.
an5.133:4.6.eng: This kind of village or town should be cultivated. This kind of village or town should not be cultivated.’

an5.133:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaññeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati bhikkhunīsu …pe… upāsakesu …pe… upāsikāsu:
an5.133:5.1.eng: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security for the nuns … laymen … laywomen, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.

an5.133:5.2.pli: ‘evarūpaṃ kāyakammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ kāyakammaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
an5.133:5.2.eng: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated. This kind of bodily action should not be cultivated.

an5.133:5.3.pli: evarūpaṃ vacīkammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ vacīkammaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
an5.133:5.3.eng: This kind of verbal action should be cultivated. This kind of verbal action should not be cultivated.

an5.133:5.4.pli: evarūpaṃ manokammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ manokammaṃ na sevitabbaṃ;
an5.133:5.4.eng: This kind of mental action should be cultivated. This kind of mental action should not be cultivated.

an5.133:5.5.pli: evarūpo ājīvo sevitabbo, evarūpo ājīvo na sevitabbo;
an5.133:5.5.eng: This kind of livelihood should be cultivated. This kind of livelihood should not be cultivated.

an5.133:5.6.pli: evarūpo gāmanigamo sevitabbo, evarūpo gāmanigamo na sevitabbo’ti.
an5.133:5.6.eng: This kind of village or town should be cultivated. This kind of village or town should not be cultivated.’

an5.133:6.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhu, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaññeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā bhikkhūsu, dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā bhikkhunīsu, dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā upāsakesu, dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā upāsikāsu dhammeneva anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavatteti;
an5.133:6.1.eng: When a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has provided just protection and security for the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen, he rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma only in a principled manner.

an5.133:6.2.pli: taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
an5.133:6.2.eng: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.”
